title: I feel like we need to do VU's by themselves again.
body: Morgana, Janna, Veigar, Maokai, etc. could all benefit from a VU but not necessarily a game play update.

Questionable whether or not the full VGUs have made the game better.  I only rarely played old Sion and Poppy, but I was pretty put off that Riot totally threw out their champion archetype in the process.  I was seriously hoping that Sion's rework would have given us two champions, one focusing on his Juggernaut archetype and the other on his Mage archetype, both tweaked for game health of course.  Instead we got something that, while certainly a really cool champion, isn't Sion.

LCS playability is not a goal of ours. We do want champions to be successful in a range of elos though. There are always going to be some champions that are stronger in a coordinated team while others are stronger in SoloQ, and that's fine. 

We do want to give every champion a unique strategic identity though, which isn't the same as having niche gameplay. 

When I say niche vs broad I'm more referring to the difference between Thresh and Bard, for example. Thresh and Bard both have awesome gameplay/art/theme and both have unique strategic identities. 

Thresh pretty much always has a much higher playrate then Bard. This isn't because Thresh is just a better champion then Bard, it's just that playmaking grim reaper is a broader theme then mysterious wandering pacifist.

I'd argue that Thresh also has a generalist kit involving engage, disengage, and the ability to save his team and immobilize teams (w/e his ult does), but I'm not the right player to go into that.

Not balancing everything around the LCS I'm personally fine with, though that does bring up the question regarding champion diversity, and how balancing that affects SoloQ.

I want to preface this by saying that it isn't my intent to be contrary, so I'll apologize in advance if it comes off that way.

In ranked play at least, Yorick is sitting at *just* under twice Galio's play rate.  Yorick was intentionally nerfed into unviability over on Rift, so it's no shocker that his play rate has roughly doubled now that he has a kit that can be balanced.  Galio is getting a rework, too.  But he isn't nearly as bad off as Yorick was.  He's unpopular, certainly, but his players are doing quite well with him.

So I guess the question is *why* is Galio getting remade?  He isn't unhealthy for the game.  He didn't get 'Eve'd' and his win rate is solid.  He's just really unpopular.  Is Galio only getting remade because of his out-dated model and unpopularity?  Because if that's the case, then he's getting remade for the people who *don't* like him rather than the people who do.

This is why the full VGUs make me uneasy.  Changes for the sake of the majority who aren't invested in a champion, the minority that already enjoyed that champ notwithstanding.  When a Poppy or Sion or Yorick remake goes live, a champion is being removed from the game and being replaced with something wholly unlike their predecessor.  Are they healthier champions for it?  Without a doubt.  But the complete loss of their identity is off-putting.

's why I'm totally okay with VGUs like the one Gangplank got.  He's VASTLY different now compared to what he was when he still had his trouser tarantula model, but he's overall a much more interesting and compelling champion while also maintaining his core identity and gameplay.
They also do things for thematic reasons. I don't know his kit, but does it give you the impression of stone gargoyle guardian?

I was thinking the same thing myself.

Corki is decently popular, unique, and a solid pick for both bottom lane and mid.  Why would he need a full VGU?

One of the major goals of champion update is to go through the older champions and modernize them. Obviously the champions with deeper problems usually get prioritized first. 

Corki is mainly on that list because his theme/visuals are pretty dated. He's a very low priority though.

A VGU is basically when we take a champion and build it from the ground up as if it was a new champion. We ask ourselves "what would this champion be like if we made this champion today, as a new champion?"

Some things stand the test of time and don't need to be changed while others don't. By the time we get to Corki we could find that most of his kit held up and doesn't need to be changed. Tristana was a full VGU for example that had pretty small gameplay changes.

A VGU just means that we change whatever makes sense to make a champion feel like a modern, cohesive champion that we would be proud to release today. It doesn't necessarily mean that it needs to have a full new kit (though in many cases with our older champions it does.)

Also sometimes changes to lore/art/theme requires gameplay changes to make the overall champion feel cohesive.
